1. Remove HoodieCommitArchiveLog use the HoodieLogFormat to archive commits
2. Introduce Avro schemas for archived commits (not used in the active timeline)
3. Archive all instants - not just commits to the archivelog

@vinothchandar @ovj Identified the root cause. It is due to my change. I will send a PR for this. @ovj is assumeDatePartitioning set as false in your job? The num partitions to clean is 0, so this bug is causing job failure.

@vinothchandar this PR focused on testing that a read from local, and write to HDFS will result in correct count of records, and this functionality should be similar between any two file systems. Our specific goal is to consider use case of reading from HDFS, writing to GCS. Will look at adding additional testing, (changed to WIP). 

Key updates are in: 
1. Every call to FSUtils.getFs() has been changed to require a basePath, from which the URI is inferred, and this PR updates every consumer of getFs(). 
2. In HoodieParquetWriter, registerFileSystem() now takes a path in order for getFs to access a path from which URI is inferred.

Sounds good. Will take a closer look sometime this week. 
What I meant was, have you been able to test this out on any real production datasets yet?
@prazanna - Fixed merge conflicts and added fix for https://github.com/uber/hoodie/issues/192 in this PR since it is related to MOR tests. Closed https://github.com/uber/hoodie/pull/194.
HoodieClean tests have been moved to TestHoodieClient. Addressed this issue in PR https://github.com/uber/hoodie/pull/189 hence closing this PR.

I am not super convinced this is necessary. This kind of temporary copies, just hurt us in the long run. I would rather downscope the test or fix what needs to be fixed before this can be done..

cc @ovj

I think this will have problems in terms of number of data files exploding. If we are creating 48 commits per day and have last savepoint as old as 30 days then we are looking at 1440 commit files and data files for all of them.  Number of commit files will still be ok if we as a part of cleanup step delete data files (latest versioned).

Data clean and Commit Archival are two different things ( you will not have data files lying around). Yes we will have as many commit files and that will be the cost you pay for paying a savepoint that is 30 days old.

yeah. the mutability/immutablity part - I punted on for now. I will explain more in person. High level, we need to make a call on if its better to list the entire table once before starting and then we can construct a nice immuatable FileSystemView object and achieve all that.. but then there are tradeoffs. but agree on your high level sentiment
So today we delete the data files when commit file for it is present? (if that file version is not latest?).
No. Let's talk offline about incremental pull and cleaner policy.
Okay, in that case, we will have to re-write HoodieReadClient to be able to support COW and MOR both. Do you think we should wait till we re-write that and then fix the tests ?
I believe this is done?

LGTM
@prazanna I've addressed all the comments.

To collect all RPC calls, we need a way to control/monitor accesses to the FileSystem object across all classes. At the moment, we use FSUtils.getFs() which returns back the vanilla FileSystem object which we have no control over. However, for any FilsSystem access in HoodieStorageWriter we register the HoodieWrapperFileSystem class and use that to read/write data. HoodieWrapperFileSystem provides a good way to monitor/control accesses to the FileSystem. We need such a wrapper to be used throughout the code. One way is to register HoodieWrapperFileSystem as part of HoodieWrite/Read Client implementations from the beginning itself, this way we have a central place to collect these metrics. To actually collect the metrics 1) we could use an accumulator in Spark 2) Create another abstraction like WriteStatus which applies to the entire DAG (although this seems like an overkill). Thoughts ?

I was actually expecting an effort similar to this. This is best accomplished by simply having all accesses to filesystem happen via `HoodieTableFileSystemView`. We are a bit away from this world. Without that, doing this seems like putting the cart in front of the horse... 
As opposed to accumulators vs writestatus, I feel we don't need either.. We simply need to account this at the driver in a predictable way and keep it much simpler..
Done as a part of https://github.com/uber/hoodie/pull/210.
Listed down the metrics here : https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Mj-L2Z0M8Cqo4A7HSseupFWzaUyTkhxPlKl78DA_f8Q/edit#gid=0

To have all filesystem accesses happen via `HoodieTableFileSystemView` and monitor them, we need abstractions of vanilla FileSystem API's like listStatus, append etc. At the moment we have this in `HoodieWrapperFileSystem`; do you think using that everywhere and making it work can be a first step ?
Made appropriate changes.
Also refer to #172 for an edge case

WrapperFileSystem for purposes of simply monitoring seems like an overkill to me. Can't we just measure the code paths calling listStatus etc from the FileSystemView.. Don't want to turn this into a monitoring library for the Hadoop FileSystem object :)
Agreed. Lets punt this until we have abstraction which localizes all the file system calls into one place. Like the FileSystemView as @vinothchandar mentioned.
@n3nash If you want to measure things like a limited fashion until then, please feel free suggest alternatives.
Will merge in once Travis builds
Looking into the failures.
@prazanna Can you take a look at the diff again ? I made some minor changes not sure if you got a chance to look at that before approving.

@vinothchandar One way to measure this quickly (just to get a sense of numbers) is to come up with a formula based on the current code base. For example Total RPC calls = [ fs.listStatus calls in index(=input rows) + (count(WriteStatus)*(fs.open + fs.close + fs.listStatus)) + some other miscellaneous fs usages ].
This will just help us understand the severity of RPC calls for the moment.
This is just to backport, NOT to be merged.
This has been backported and fixed in master.https://github.com/uber/hoodie/pull/216 and https://github.com/uber/hoodie/pull/213

High level comment. This approach seems to duplicate a lot of code and maintaining double versions for classes that are in hoodie-mr and hoodie-hive. I am afraid we probably need to think about a better way of separating out classes where imports are different..  
for e.g: maintianing two versions of HoodieInputFormat would be really cumbersome.
@vinothchandar I agree on the code duplication.

The build is failing since the maven build log has exceeded the max configure `(4MB)` on jenkins. It is currently at about `4.7 MB` as opposed to generally at `3 MB`. The contributing factor for this increase is excessive logs from `INFO: org.apache.parquet.hadoop.ColumnChunkPageWriteStore` probably due to more tests added to the project.
Unless I'm missing your point here, while creating a new HoodieKey as part of a new HoodieRecord, you should be able to set whatever partitionPath you like, including a date.
Interesting, what sort of a job are you running ? Can you share some more details ?
